pageData.text: In this series of hands-on activities, students will learn about the biological, environmental, and chemical mechanisms that are associated with acid rain. First, students will determine the pH of unpolluted rain and observe the effect of acid rain on seed germination. Then, students will investigate the buffering effects of different types of soil.

pageData.text: Acid rain occurs when water vapor in the atmosphere mixes with sulfur- or nitrogen-containing compounds in the atmosphere, creating an acid which can erode buildings, harm aquatic ecosystems, and damage soil microbes. On Earth, thankfully, acid rain is a relatively rare phenomenon which scientists have been working to remediate for decades. On Venus, however, acid rain forms continually in the upper atmosphere. Because Venus has extensive volcanic activity, compounds such as sulfur dioxide gas are constantly released into the atmosphere; on Earth, these are released in small quantities from fossil fuel consumption. These compounds mix with water vapor to form sulfuric acid. Unlike Earth, the surface of Venus is about 480 Â°C, thanks to its intensive greenhouse effect, which is too hot for liquid precipitation to fall; instead, the acid rain evaporates and persists in clouds of sulfuric acid droplets. Observing these weather patterns on Venus gives scientists a good idea of what the worst-case scenario could be on Earth if higher quantities of pollutants are released into the atmosphere or if greenhouse gas levels rise considerably<sup>1</sup>.

pageData.subTitle: The Hydrologic Cycle
pageData.text: As precipitation falls, carbon dioxide present in the atmosphere dissolves in the water and reacts to form carbonic acid, H2CO3, which is a weak acid. For this reason, unpolluted rainwater is acidic, with a pH value around 5.6.
CO2(g) + H2O(l) H2CO3(aq)

When precipitation reaches the ground, it runs off into surface water or infiltrates the soil. The water that infiltrates the soil percolates through permeable rock and into groundwater. Both surface water and groundwater proceed to the ocean. Water returns to the atmosphere when surface water or ocean water evaporates, and plants transpire (Figure 1).

pageData.subTitle: Acid Deposition
pageData.text: Despite significant reductions in air pollutant emissions over the past 30 years, remains a threat to man-made structures, aquatic organisms, forests, and human health. The process of acid deposition begins when gaseous sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides (nitrogen monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, and dinitrogen monoxide) are released into the atmosphere and react with oxygen and water to form sulfuric and nitric acids as well as sulfate and nitrate salts. This is most commonly encountered as acid rain, but may also include acidic snow, clouds, and fog. Figure 2 shows the formulas for these chemical reactions.

pageData.subTitle: Areas Impacted by Acid Deposition
pageData.text: The major sources of sulfur dioxide emission in the United States are coal-burning electric utilities (70%), whereas the major sources in Canada are industrial plants (60%). Emitted gases rise into the atmosphere, where they are carried from west to east and northeast by prevailing westerly winds. These winds can disperse the pollutants hundreds of miles from their source. In fact, most of the acid deposition that affects the northeast United States and eastern Canada originates in the Midwest region of the United States. As these gases get carried by the winds, they react with oxygen and water to form sulfuric and nitric acids, as well as sulfate and nitrate particles. Acid deposition is a regional rather than global problem because of the limited force of the wind currents. Nevertheless, winds can carry air pollutants over political borders and create tension between neighboring countries. For example, tensions ran high in the late 1980s when it was found that air pollutants originating in the U.S. were being blown into Canada.

Major areas affected by acid deposition include the northeastern United States and southeastern Canada. Acid deposition in these regions is intensified due to the large number of factories and coal-fired power plants in the Midwestern United States. Areas of Central Europe and Scandinavia are also affected by acid deposition due to directional winds carrying pollutants from factories in Great Britain and other European countries. Large areas of Asia, including India and China, are also affected by acid deposition due to their reliance on coal-fired plants for energy and industrial production needs.

pageData.subTitle: Effects of Acid Deposition
pageData.text: affects plants, human-made structures, surface water, aquatic organisms, and human health. It damages the leaves and bark of trees, impairing the ability of trees to photosynthesize, leaving them vulnerable to insects and disease. The acid burns leaves by removing the outer coating, leaving brown spots. Acid deposition also leaches nutrients, such as calcium and magnesium, from the soil, depriving already weakened trees of essential minerals. Acid also releases aluminum ions, that were once attached to minerals, into the soil, potentially damaging plant roots. Trees at higher elevations are especially susceptible, because cloud vapor can be 10 to 100 times more acidic than acid rain and can bathe trees in acid for days at a time. As water evaporates from the acidic raindrops on a plant, the acidity of the raindrops can increase.

Acid deposition can deteriorate certain materials and corrode certain metals. Many ancient statues and buildings are made of marble and limestone, two forms of calcium carbonate (CaCO<sub>3</sub>). The Colosseum in Rome and the Taj Mahal in India both show signs of degradation caused by acid deposition.

Perhaps the best-known effect of acid deposition is the acidification of surface water and the resultant harm to aquatic organisms. As fish and amphibians develop, their eggs are particularly sensitive to changes in pH. Although tolerance varies by species, fish eggs generally will not hatch in water with a pH of 5 or lower. Suboptimal pH is not necessarily lethal, but it often leads to lower body weight and smaller size, making fish more vulnerable to predation and less able to compete for food. As previously stated, acid deposition releases aluminum ions that are separated from minerals in nearby soils. When these ions enter the surface waters, they stimulate excessive mucus formation in fish. This mucus clogs gills and ultimately asphyxiates many types of fish. A decline in the number of pH-sensitive organisms can significantly disrupt an ecosystem and seriously affect the food web.

Acid deposition affects more than just the pH of water; the influx of nitrogen from nitric acid deposition into surface waters can lead to eutrophic conditions. Symptoms of eutrophication include algal blooms, declines in the health of fish and shellfish, and decreases in dissolved oxygen levels. Eutrophic conditions brought about by anthropogenic sources such as acid deposition can greatly threaten the biodiversity of aquatic ecosystems.

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) conducted a National Surface Water Survey to determine how many lakes and streams were affected by chronic acidity and the percentage of these waters that were this way due to acid deposition. The survey revealed that acid deposition is responsible for approximately 75% of acidified lakes and 50% of acidified streams. The affected areas include the Adirondacks, the mid-Appalachian highlands, the upper Midwest, and high-elevation West. In areas such as the northeastern U.S., where there is poor buffering capacity, some lakes now have a pH lower than 5. Little Echo Pond in Franklin, New York, is one of the most acidic lakes reported, with a pH of 4.2.

Some soils and water systems are better able to resist changes in pH. Typically, soils with higher clay content (or water systems located where there is clay content in the soil) are better able to resist the change in pH because of the chemical composition of the soil. The chemicals act as a <button class='glossary-text'>buffer</button>, in that they react with the acid first and prevent an immediate change in the pH of the soil or water. This buffering helps prevent large changes in pH if there is only occasional <button class='glossary-text'>acid deposition</button>. If there is a large amount, or continual acid deposition, the pH would still decrease, but typically this will occur at a slower rate than at locations without this buffer.

Acid deposition does not cause direct harm to people; however, the pollutants that cause acid deposition can directly affect human health. Lung cancer, asthma, bronchitis, and emphysema can be caused and/or aggravated by air pollutants. For example, the prevalence of respiratory ailments is 50% higher in the most polluted areas of Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic than in the cleaner areas of those countries. Senior citizens, children, and people with weakened immune systems are advised to stay inside during times of peak air pollution in many metropolitan cities.

pageData.subTitle: Solutions
pageData.text: Title IV of the Clean Air Act Amendments, enacted in 1990, contains provisions to regulate the emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide compounds. The EPA established the Allowance Trading System in 1995 under which regulated companies are allocated permits, called allowances, which allow them to emit one ton of sulfur dioxide per allowance. The allowances may be allocated through the year or or saved for future use. Companies can even buy, sell, or trade allowances. Nitrogen oxides are controlled by a rate-based regulatory system that sets a limit on the pounds of nitrogen oxides per million British thermal units (lbs/mmBTUs) emitted by every power plantâs boilers.

One way coal-fired power plants can reduce sulfur dioxide emissions is to burn coal with lower sulfur content. Low-sulfur coal contains 0â1% sulfur, and high-sulfur coal contains 2â4% sulfur. Sulfur dioxide emissions can also be reduced through the installation of wet scrubbers at coal-fired power plants. Though costly to install at existing power plants, scrubbers can remove 80â95% of emitted sulfur dioxides. Another method, fluidized bed combustion, creates an environment in which combustion can occur at a lower temperature and the gases released come into contact with sulfur-absorbing materials. Sulfur-absorbing chemicals, such as limestone, then capture the sulfur oxides before they are released into the environment. Lower amounts of nitrogen oxides are also formed at these lower combustion temperatures. This process reduces emissions of sulfur oxides by approximately 90% and nitrogen oxides by Figure 3 also shows some solutions and summarizes the effects of acid rain on an entire environment.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, you will prepare acidic water solutions and simulated acid rain. In activity 1, you will add the filter paper to the 4 Petri dishes, wet the filter papers with the designated pH solution and place the seeds in each dish. Then, you will allow the seeds to germinate. You will then record the number of seeds that have been germinated each day for 3 days. In activity 2, you will prepare by collecting 2 different soil samples. Then, you will determine the buffering capacity of bottled water. Next, you will mix each soil sample with bottled water and allow the mixtures to settle overnight. Then, you will decant the eluent from each soil sample. Finally, you will determine the buffering capacity of each soil sample.

typeBefore.title: Prepare Acid Dilutions (8 steps)
typeBefore.text: Prepare the vinegar dilutions and the simulated acid rain solution. This method of solution preparation is known as a <button class='glossary-text'>serial dilution</button>. This is a stepwise process and typically the justprepared solution is used to create the next, more dilute solution.

pageData.text: Add 80 mL of bottled water to the 100 mL graduated cylinder. Then pour 20 mL of vinegar into the graduated cylinder to create 100 mL of 0.18 M acetic acid solution.
Pour the 0.18 M solution into a plastic cup and using the permanent marker, label the plastic cup â0.18 M acetic acid.â Swirl the solution slowly for a few seconds.
Rinse out the graduated cylinder with bottled water.
Add 90 mL of bottled water to the graduated cylinder. Then pour 10 mL of the 0.18 M solution into the graduated cylinder to create 100 mL of 0.018 M acetic acid solution.
Pour the 0.018 M solution into a different plastic cup and label the plastic cup â0.018 M acetic acid.â Swirl the solution slowly for a few seconds.
Rinse out the graduated cylinder with bottled water
Add 90 mL of bottled water to the graduated cylinder. Then pour 10 mL of the 0.018 M solution into the graduated cylinder to create 100 mL of 0.0018 M acetic acid solution.
Pour the 0.0018 M solution into a different plastic cup and label the cup âSimulated acid rain.â Swirl the solution slowly for a few seconds.
In Activity 1, you will germinate lettuce seeds with water at different pHs to determine the effect of acid rain on seed germination. You will observe the germination over 3 days.

typeBefore.text: For this activity, the higher concentration acetic acid solutions will be used to simulate the effect of continual acid precipitation on germination, leading to pH values lower than those resulting from just a single occurrence of acid rain.

pageData.text: Place a piece of filter paper into each of the 4 Petri dishes.
Using the permanent marker, label one Petri dish lid âBottled water.â
Label the remaining 3 Petri dish lids with the concentrations of the different acetic acid solutions (simulated acid rain, 0.018 M acetic and 0.18 M acetic acid, respectively).

Using a clean pipet for each solution, add ~7 mL of each of the four solutions to its respective dish on top of the filter paper. Use the graduations marked on the plastic pipet to measure the 7 mL. Go from lowest concentration to highest concentration (i.e.,bottled water, to simulated acid rain, to 0.018 M acetic acid, to 0.18 M acetic acid).
Note: Keep pipets with their respective solutions for use in Activity 2.
Drain any excess liquid into a sink.
Place 20 lettuce seeds in each Petri dish on top of the saturated filter paper. Cover each Petri dish with its respective lid.
Place the covered Petri dishes in a room temperature well lit location where they will not be disturbed (preferably on a windowsill).

Observe the seeds in the dishes for 3 consecutive days after setup. In Data Table 1, record the total number of seeds that have germinated each day. Germination has occurred when the seed coat splits and the first root begins to emerge from the seed. Take photographs of the 4 Petri dishes to show the seed germination on each day

pageData.text: Continue with Activity 2 while waiting for seeds to germinate. Rinse out the â0.18 M acetic acidâ and â0.018 M acetic acidâ plastic cups for use in Activity 2.
In Activity 2, you will compare the ability of soil to resist changes in pH. You will need to collect two soil samples. This activity requires 2 days to complete.

typeBefore.text: For this activity, collect small soil samples (just enough to fill the 250 mL beaker and the additional plastic cup to 1 cm high) of 2 different soil types. For example, they can be from multiple outdoor areas, commercial potting soil, clay, sand, etc. Collect one soil sample in the extra plastic cup from your equipment kit and collect the other in the 250 mL beaker. You will test to see how well each soil type resists changes to pH when exposed to acidic conditions. The simulated acid rain solution (0.0018 M acetic acid solution) will be used in this experiment to simulate acid rain exposure. This will be a 2 day process as the soil sample/water mixture needs to settle for 24 hours.

pageData.text: Using the 100 mL graduated cylinder, measure 100 mL of water from the âBottled waterâ solution cup and pour it into a 250 mL beaker. Rinse the graduated cylinder with bottled water.

Add 10 drops of Bogen Universal Indicator to the beaker of bottled water and gently swirl until mixed. Record the initial color and pH of the âBottled waterâ solution in Data Table 2 by comparing it to the Bogen Universal Indicator Chart.

Use the designated pipet to add 5 mL of âSimulated acid rainâ solution from the plastic cup to the beaker containing the âBottled waterâ solution and Bogen Universal Indicator. Swirl the beaker after the 5 mL addition. Record the color and pH of the âBottled waterâ solution in Data Table 2 under âBottled water.â

Continue adding and swirling the âSimulated acid rainâ solution in 5 mL increments until a total of 15 mL of âSimulated acid rainâ solution has been added. Be sure to record the color and pH of the solution after each addition in Data Table 2. Take a photograph of the solution after next to the Bogen Universal Indicator Chart the 15 mL have been added.

pageData.text: When the samples are settled, using one of the rinsed plastic cups from Activity 1, slowly pour off the liquid of the settled soil sample into a separate plastic cup, and label it âSample 1.â Dispose of the soil at the bottom of the beaker/plastic cup (from Day 1) into the household trash and rinse out this item.

A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, you will prepare acidic water solutions and simulated acid rain. In activity 1, you will add the filter paper to the 4 Petri dishes, wet the filter papers with the designated pH solution and place the seeds in each dish. Then, you will allow the seeds to germinate. You will then record the number of seeds that have been germinated each day for 3 days. In activity 2, you will prepare by collecting 2 different soil samples. Then, you will determine the buffering capacity of bottled water. Next, you will mix each soil sample with bottled water and allow the mixtures to settle overnight. Then, you will decant the eluent from each soil sample. Finally, you will determine the buffering capacity of each soil sample.

data.title: Acid deposition
data.content: the accumulation of acids or acidic compounds on the surface of the Earth, in lakes or streams, or on objects or vegetation; also called acid rain

data.title: Buffer
data.content: a substance that prevents drastic changes in pH

data.title: Serial dilution
data.content: a stepwise process in which a just-prepared solution is used to create the next, more dilute solution
